results.headline: Light and Shadow, and Music on the Wondrous, Dreamy Side
results.summary_short: Pedro Costa’s unusual documentary “Ne Change Rien,” about the French singer and actress Jeanne Balibar, focuses on work — the performer’s mix of inspiration and hard labor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ne change rien

results.headline: Earthquakes and Seismic Suffering
results.summary_short: Feng Xiaogang’s “Aftershock,” a huge hit in China, traces 30 fraught years in the life of a mother, beginning with a natural disaster in 1976 and ending with another one in 2008.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aftershock

results.headline: Ending a Lethal Game and All Its Gory Details
results.summary_short: In “Saw 3D,” its makers say the horror-film franchise is bringing its punishing schedule to a close.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saw 3D

results.headline: From a Universe of Trash, Recycling Art and Hope
results.summary_short: Lucy Walker’s inspiring documentary profiles Brazilian catadores, or trash pickers, and the artist Vik Muniz.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waste Land

results.headline: Even the Tiniest Actions Can Change Entire Lives
results.summary_short: “A Small Act” follows Chris Mburu, who, as a child in Africa, was sponsored by Hilde Back, a woman in Sweden.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Small Act

results.headline: Alien Invaders, Earthling Romance
results.summary_short: “Monsters” is a wondrously atmospheric drama from the young British filmmaker Gareth Edwards.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monsters

results.headline: Brenda, Eddie, Billy and Friends Bury a Ballpark
results.summary_short: The story of two memorable concerts in 2008, and of the stadium where they were held.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Play at Shea

results.headline: From the Past, a Future Blank and Open
results.summary_short: In Doug Block’s remarkable documentary “The Kids Grow Up,” the viewer becomes absorbed into the family as a daughter matures.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kids Grow Up

results.headline: Time to Die; Join Me for a Drink?
results.summary_short: “Wild Target,” directed by Jonathan Lynn, is a remake of a French film and stars Bill Nighy and Emily Blunt.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Target

results.headline: A Tidy Home, Cluttered With Weighty Emotions
results.summary_short: Kristen Stewart upends the lives of James Gandolfini and Melissa Leo, who portray grieving parents in Jake Scott’s “Welcome to the Rileys.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome to the Rileys

results.headline: Searching for Stability
results.summary_short: “Jolene,” starring Jessica Chastain, follows a woman on her 10-year search for happiness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jolene

results.headline: A Detective Who Solves Crimes for a Living, and as a Pastime
results.summary_short: Claude Chabrol’s film “Inspector Bellamy” starts off hinting at death, but violence and grief play less of a role in this murder mystery than you might expect.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inspector Bellamy

results.headline: In Trilogy’s Finale, Tough Girl Rages Against Villains of Society
results.summary_short: “The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest” feels like the concluding chapter it is, with neatly tied loose ends and closing remarks, though it unfolds as something of a secular passion play.
results.display_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest

results.headline: Churchill During the War, Armed With Inspiration
results.summary_short: “Winston Churchill: Walking With Destiny” is a glowing biography of the wartime prime minister.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winston Churchill: Walking With Destiny

results.headline: Ogled and Threatened on a Journey to Womanhood
results.summary_short: Hélène Cattet and Bruno Forzani’s “Amer” is a protracted erotic tease in which a female protagonist is observed from childhood to adulthood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amer

results.headline: A Musician Who Imparts a Glum Kind of Grandeur
results.summary_short: The documentary “Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields” takes an intimate look at this performer.
results.display_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt and the Magnetic Fields

results.headline: Don’t Spirits Ever Knock Anymore?
results.summary_short: “Paranormal Activity 2” retains the stripped-down aesthetic of its predecessor from 2007, but with more cameras and a (slightly) bigger budget.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paranormal Activity 2

results.headline: Pretty Women and Plenty of Cows
results.summary_short: Who knows why “Milk and Money,” a daffy, enjoyable little film from 1996, never got much of a look the first time around. But it’s a treat to look at now.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Milk and Money

results.headline: Tragic Love Tale of Spirits and Samurai
results.summary_short: “Kuroneko,” a Japanese movie from 1968, seen in a new print, includes two avenging female spirits and brutal samurai.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kuroneko

results.headline: Sweat, Blood and Philosophy to the Rhythms of the Sweet Science
results.summary_short: Frederick Wiseman’s latest documentary, “Boxing Gym,” explores a corner of Texas that welcomes all comers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boxing Gym
